results.title: Islam
results.creator_credit: David Millar, James Beveridge and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Great Religions”.
Like Christianity, Islam is winning converts, particularly in North Africa. This film explores the faith of the Muslims, taking you to Mecca, birthplace of the Prophet Mohamed, and to the shrine of Islam’s holy of holies, the Ka’aba, or Cube. Following the routes of Muslim conquest, you see shrines of holy men and heroes from Cairo to Pakistan. Wherever you go in this vast empire, the power of Islam is apparent in soaring domes and noble architecture of great cities. Against this background the film relates the history of Mohamed and his rise to leadership, spiritual and temporal. Narrated by Douglas Rain.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Millar, James Beveridge and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Hinduism
results.creator_credit: David Millar, James Beveridge and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Great Religions”.
In India, the home of most present adherents, this film traces the history of Hinduism, its evolution over the centuries and its connections to Buddhism and Jainism. Shown are the observances of this faith, its teaching of non-violence, its respect for all living things, how the social order created by it has been modified in the modern world to outlaw the declaration of individuals as “untouchables” and to remove limitations on freedom imposed by caste.

group_works.title: The Grapes of wrath
group_works.creator_credit: Arthur Barron and C B S

results.title: The Grapes of wrath
results.creator_credit: Arthur Barron and C B S
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Great American novel”.
Compares the situation of the farm families of the 1920s as portrayed in Steinbeck’s “Grapes of Wrath” to the situations faced by the Appalachian migrants and negroes of today.

results.title: Babbit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Great American novel”.
Discusses the parallels between American middle class society as it is today to that of forty years ago as depicted in the novels “Babbitt”, by Sinclair Lewis and “Grapes of Wrath” by John Steinbeck.

results.title: Gods and men
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Grandeur that Was Rome”.
Famous British archaeologist Sir Mortimer Wheeler introduces the story of Christian influence on the degraded Roman Empire, with its cynical worship of gods. A message and belief was brought to spiritually empty Rome.

group_siblings.title: Skeleton of an empire

results.title: Skeleton of an empire
results.creator_credit: Stephen Hearst and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Grandeur that Was Rome”.
Sir Mortimer Wheeler surveys the remains of the Roman Empire and examines its great length and breadth, from Hadrian’s Wall in northern England to the southern perimeter in the Sahara, from Merida in Spain eastwards to Jerash in Jordan.

results.title: Roman art and architecture
results.creator_credit: Stephen Hearst and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Grandeur that Was Rome”.
A discussion of ancient Rome’s art and architecture, particularly of functional constructions such as aqueducts, and of domes and large interiors.
